<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 574]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 605]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 856, 636]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
The times taken by members of a large quiz club to complete a challenge have a normal distribution with mean \(\mu\) minutes. The times, \(x\) minutes, are recorded for a random sample of 8 members of the club. The results are summarised as follows, where \(\overline{x}\) is the sample mean.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 133, 640, 152]]<|/det|>
\[\overline{x} = 33.8\qquad \Sigma (x - \overline{x})^2 = 94.5\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 164, 415, 183]]<|/det|>
Find a \(95\%\) confidence interval for \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|> A scientist is investigating the size of shells at various beach locations. She selects four beach locations and takes a random sample of shells from each of these beaches. She classifies each shell as large or small. Her results are summarised in the following table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 128, 920, 256]]<|/det|>
Beach locationTotal
\(A\)\(B\)\(C\)\(D\)
Size of shellLarge68699681314
Small28556439186
Total96124160120500
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|> Test, at the \(10\%\) significance level, whether the size of shell is independent of the beach location. [7] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 308, 915, 326]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 922, 106]]<|/det|>
A manager claims that the lengths of the rubber tubes that his company produces have a median of \(5.50 \text{cm}\). The lengths, in cm, of a random sample of 11 tubes produced by this company are as follows.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 117, 203, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>5.56</label>

<label>5.58</label>

<label>5.54</label>

<label>5.52</label>

<label>5.59</label>

<label>5.51</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[688, 117, 712, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>5.61</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 200, 920, 234]]<|/det|>
It is required to test at the \(10\%\) significance level the null hypothesis that the population median length is \(5.50 \text{cm}\) against the alternative hypothesis that the population median length is not equal to \(5.50 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 247, 920, 281]]<|/det|>
Show that both a sign test and a Wilcoxon signed-rank test give the same conclusion and state this conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 262, 920, 281]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
A company has two machines, \(A\) and \(B\), which independently fill small bottles with a liquid. The volumes of liquid per bottle, in suitable units, filled by machines \(A\) and \(B\) are denoted by \(x\) and \(y\) respectively. A scientist at the company takes a random sample of 40 bottles filled by machine \(A\) and a random sample of 50 bottles filled by machine \(B\). The results are summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 147, 791, 168]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma x = 1120\qquad \Sigma x^2 = 31400\qquad \Sigma y = 1370\qquad \Sigma y^2 = 37600\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 920, 217]]<|/det|>
The population means of the volumes of liquid in the bottles filled by machines \(A\) and \(B\) are denoted by \(\mu_{A}\) and \(\mu_{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 227, 144, 245]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 227, 824, 246]]<|/det|>
Test at the \(2\%\) significance level whether there is any difference between \(\mu_{A}\) and \(\mu_{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 227, 917, 245]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(\alpha\) for which there would be evidence at the \(\alpha \%\) significance level that \(\mu_A - \mu_B\) is greater than 0.25.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
